title: Neyman–Pearson lemma
text:
In <a href="statistics">statistics</a>, the Neyman–Pearson <a href="lemma%20%28mathematics%29">lemma</a> was introduced by <a href="Jerzy%20Neyman">Jerzy Neyman</a> and <a href="Egon%20Pearson">Egon Pearson</a> in a paper in 1933. The Neyman-Pearson lemma is part of the Neyman-Pearson theory of statistical testing, which introduced concepts like <a href="Type%20I%20and%20type%20II%20errors%23Type%20II%20error">errors of the second kind</a>, <a href="Power%20of%20a%20test">power function</a>, and inductive behavior.<ref name="org/euclid.ndml">Wald: Chapter II: The Neyman-Pearson Theory of Testing a Statistical Hypothesis: <a href="https%3A//projecteuclid.org/euclid.ndml/1175196981">Wald: Chapter II: The Neyman-Pearson Theory of Testing a Statistical Hypothesis</a></ref> The previous Fisherian theory of significance testing postulated only one hypothesis. By introducing a competing hypothesis, the Neyman-Pearsonian flavor of statistical testing allows investigating the <a href="Type%20I%20and%20type%20II%20errors">two types of errors</a>. The trivial cases where one always rejects or accepts the null hypothesis are of little interest but it does prove that one must not relinquish control over one type of error while calibrating the other. Neyman and Pearson accordingly proceeded to restrict their attention to the class of all formula_1 level tests while subsequently minimizing type II error, traditionally denoted by formula_2. Their seminal paper of 1933, including the Neyman-Pearson lemma, comes at the end of this endeavor, not only showing the existence of tests with the most <a href="Power%20of%20a%20test">power</a> that retain a prespecified level of type I error (formula_1), but also providing a way to construct such tests. <a href="Uniformly%20most%20powerful%20test%23The%20Karlin-Rubin%20theorem">The Karlin-Rubin theorem</a> extends the Neyman-Pearson lemma to settings involving composite hypotheses with monotone likelihood ratios.

Note that the most powerful test may not always be unique as can be inferred from the lemma. In fact, it may not exist at all.
In practice, the <a href="likelihood%20ratio">likelihood ratio</a> is often used directly to construct tests — see <a href="likelihood-ratio%20test">likelihood-ratio test</a>. However it can also be used to suggest particular test-statistics that might be of interest or to suggest simplified tests — for this, one considers algebraic manipulation of the ratio to see if there are key statistics in it related to the size of the ratio (i.e. whether a large statistic corresponds to a small ratio or to a large one).

Application in economics.
A variant of the Neyman–Pearson lemma has found an application in the seemingly unrelated domain of the economics of land value. One of the fundamental problems in <a href="consumer%20theory">consumer theory</a> is calculating the <a href="demand%20function">demand function</a> of the consumer given the prices. In particular, given a heterogeneous land-estate, a price measure over the land, and a subjective utility measure over the land, the consumer's problem is to calculate the best land parcel that he can buy – i.e. the land parcel with the largest utility, whose price is at most his budget. It turns out that this problem is very similar to the problem of finding the most powerful statistical test, and so the Neyman–Pearson lemma can be used.
Uses in electrical engineering.
The Neyman–Pearson lemma is quite useful in <a href="electronics%20engineering">electronics engineering</a>, namely in the design and use of <a href="radar">radar</a> systems, <a href="data%20transmission">digital communication system</a>s, and in <a href="signal%20processing">signal processing</a> systems. 
In radar systems, the Neyman–Pearson lemma is used in first setting the rate of <a href="False%20positives%20and%20false%20negatives%23False%20negative%20error">missed detection</a>s to a desired (low) level, and then minimizing the rate of <a href="False%20positives%20and%20false%20negatives%23False%20positive%20error">false alarm</a>s, or vice versa.
Neither false alarms nor missed detections can be set at arbitrarily low rates, including zero. All of the above goes also for many systems in signal processing.
Uses in particle physics.
The Neyman–Pearson lemma is applied to the construction of analysis-specific likelihood-ratios, used to e.g. test for signatures of <a href="new%20physics">new physics</a> against the nominal <a href="Standard%20Model">Standard Model</a> prediction in proton-proton collision datasets collected at the <a href="Large%20Hadron%20Collider">LHC</a>.
